text: - Hi, and welcome back to our masterclass
on Data Governance with AWS.
I'm Kevin Lewis, and to this point,

we've been talking a lot
about data governance,
strategy, people, process, you know,

all of the things that are
necessary to get a program
off the ground and to sustain it.
I'd also like to talk a little bit

about the supporting technology
that can help accelerate it.

And so there's, we talked
about a number of areas

within a data governance
and the data management
practices that support it.

And so it's really
important to understand some
of the tools that are available to you.
So we at AWS have a number of tools
that can help support this process.
So I'm gonna run through a list of those.
It is by no means a complete list

and we also have a partner
community that can help

with the full range of
data governance capability

with all of the capabilities
we talked about.
But to give you a few examples,
so first we have Amazon DataZone

and this is a data
catalog that can help data

producers contribute their
data to a data catalog
and it will help the end user community

find the data they're looking
for within the catalog.

So it provides sort of a
portal that you can use

to share data among
producers and consumers

and make it easy to access and
find the data that's needed

both for analytics and for
application development.

Also, AWS Glue, so this covers
things like data integration.

So if I'm pulling data
from multiple sources,
I can minimize manual coding
but it also includes information

and capabilities around
data quality management,

so data profiling, you know,
data quality rules management,

things that help you with
the ongoing observation
and improvement of data quality over time.

And then in the area of
security and privacy,
there are many capabilities.
One such example is Amazon Macie.
So this can help you scan across your data
and look for sensitive information

such as personally
identifiable information
but you can also enter your own attributes

of sensitive information
and it can help find
that sensitive data wherever it lives
in your cloud ecosystem.
And then we have AWS Lake Formation.
So this helps to build data lakes

around S3 and helps
you with access rights.

And it can do things like
tag-based access control.

So we can mark objects within
the data lake associated

with particular business
areas or data domains.
And then it can also do things
like fine-grained access control
at the column level and the row level.

Also Amazon QuickSight,
so QuickSight itself,

in order to build things
like dashboards and reports,

it has capabilities to
do some transformation
of data into those dashboards.

But in addition, you can
use QuickSight directly

for some sophisticated monitoring
of data quality issues.
So just like you're using QuickSight

to create dashboards
around business use cases,

one of those can be monitoring
the data quality itself.

So you can use QuickSight
to create dashboards
to help you monitor data quality
and visualize any issues that you find.

Then in the area of
artificial intelligence

and machine learning,
we have Amazon SageMaker

to help you build and deploy
models into production.

And within generative AI,
SageMaker offers a library

of third-party models that are
available through SageMaker.

And specifically we have Amazon
Bedrock for generative AI.
And so Amazon Bedrock provides access
to third-party generative AI models
as well as Amazon's own Titan models.
And one of the benefits of Bedrock

is that you can keep your
internal data private.

So we make sure that as
you are feeding models

for customization and fine
tuning with your own data,
that data can be locked
into your own environment and not used

as a basis for training the
foundation model itself.
And you can do also interesting things
to monitor the output.

We talked about looking for
things like toxicity and bias.
You can use things like Amazon Comprehend
to look for sentiment analysis.
So in much the same way you would look

at text data to look for
toxicity issues in general,

you can look at the output
of generative AI models

through a tool like
Comprehend to make sure

that the output of the models
is within your guidelines.

Also, there's tools
like Amazon Rekognition
so that you can monitor, you know,
output of images and you can look

for any issues as it relates
to images that get created.
So there's, again, a wide variety
of tools that are available.
That's just a small list.
Also, again, the partner ecosystem
can help you cover every aspect
of a data governance and machine learning.
Okay, so we've covered a lot of ground

and so let's try to summarize
a little bit of, you know,
what can you do on Monday?
What can you do to get started

with all of the things
that we've talked about?
Well, it'll be no surprise

at this point that I'll
say the first thing

to do is to identify some
targeted business initiatives,
whether that's within the AIML space
or whether it's, you know,

targeting packaged applications
that are being delivered.

Any major initiative that's
funded, that's somebody else's,
within somebody else's organization
outside of the data team,
then you can position data governance
to support those other programs.
That's where to start.
So identify at least one major
business initiative to support.
Then take a look at the underlying data
that's needed to support that initiative.
So what is the condition of that data?
What kind of issues do you know about
that need to be addressed?

Position data governance
to support and ensure

that that data is ready and
in a condition necessary

for that business
initiative to be successful.

And then, again,
prioritize the people part
of it where, you know, which data stewards

are you going to assign
to which data domains
and which data owners need to be in place?

Because we've targeted
specific business initiatives,

we understand the data
that's needed to support it,

we understand the data issues
that need to be addressed,
that's when we can figure out

how to take people and data
management capabilities,
put them together and plan them out

specifically to support
near-term initiatives.

And again, with every step,
you're gonna do two things.
You're going to deliver

near-term business value
and small scope efforts

but you're also gonna build
your capability over time.
And so every project is gonna contribute

to the maturity of your
data governance capability

while you're also delivering
near-term business value.
